journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Analysis of externally pressurized multirecess conical hybrid journal bearing system using micropolar lubricant

article-meta.aff: Tribology Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, India

author-notes.corresp: Arvind K Rajput, Tribology Laboratory, Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Roorkee, Uttrakhand 247667, India. Email: arvind.mechei@gmail.com

abstract.p: This article describes an analytical study to demonstrate the influence of micropolar lubricant on a four-pocket conical hybrid journal bearing system compensated with membrane restrictor. The modified Reynolds equation has been derived using Eringen’s theory of micropolar fluids with usual assumptions in cylindrical coordinates. The finite element modeling of the modified Reynolds equation has been made using Galerkin’s technique. The variation of bearing characteristics parameters for both Newtonian and micropolar lubricated bearings have been plotted with respect to radial load parameter for the chosen values of semi-cone angles, coupling number, characteristic length, and membrane compliance. The numerically simulated results indicate that micropolar lubricated bearing provides enhanced performance vis-à-vis Newtonian lubricated bearing.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In many industrial applications that requires radial as well as axial load to be supported simultaneously, the use of a conical journal bearing is made. The conical journal bearings are generally used in high-speed turbine, precision machine tools such as lathes, grinding machines, etc. The conical journal bearing system is advantageous to use for the view point of lubricant flow rate, adjustability of clearance and space.1–3

In recent times, many studies4–13 related to conical bearing have been reported in the literature. Prabhu and Ganesan4–6 studied the dynamic behavior of capillary compensated annular recess conical hydrostatic thrust bearings. They studied the conditions of tilt, eccentricity, and rotation in their analysis. Khalil et al.7 investigated the influence of turbulent lubrication on the performance of externally pressurized circular and conical thrust bearings. Rahman8 used the averaged clearance method to solve the equation of stationary pressure distribution in the flow between the conic surfaces. Yoshimoto et al.9,10 investigated water-lubricated hydrostatic conical bearings with spiral grooves for high-speed spindles. Ingle and Ahuja11 designed an experimental setup to study the performance characteristics of the carbon–epoxy shaft in aerostatic conical journal bearing at high speeds in the range 10,000–65,000 r/min. Very recently, Sharma et al.12 carried out an analytical study of a four-pocket hydrostatic conical journal bearing system. They extended their study further by considering the influence of wear in the analysis of a four-pocket orifice compensated hybrid conical journal bearing system.13

The use of a flow control device in a hydrostatic bearing system is rather inevitable. It is a well-known fact that the stiffness of externally pressurized journal bearings depends on the type of compensating device used. The variable flow restrictor called as membrane restrictor was first used by DeGast.14 Cusano15 carried out a study of externally pressurized journal bearings compensated by membrane restrictor. His study indicates that the stiffness of these bearings can be increased using variable-flow restrictors rather than fixed restrictors. In recent times, many studies16–18 were performed to investigate the performance of an externally pressurized journal bearing compensating with membrane restrictor. These studies indicate that the performance of bearing system in terms of fluid film stiffness and damping coefficients significantly improves with membrane restrictor. The studies5–18 are restricted up to Newtonian lubricant.

Owing to a rapid technological advancement, number of applications need a lubricant that suits a specific properties. Polymer additives are mixed to the Newtonian lubricants to improve their performance. These polymer additives have the different flow characteristics than the parent fluid. The additive package consists of various chemical compounds which are added in specific concentrations to attain desired performance characteristics. These additives include a mix of anti-wear, anti-friction, corrosion inhibitor, VI improver, extreme pressure, etc. This blend of additive and the base oil dominates the rheological behavior within the bearing contact. Therefore, the lubricant no longer behaves as a Newtonian fluid. There are many theories available in the literature to describe the flow characteristics of non-Newtonian fluids such as electrorheological fluid, coupled stress fluid, and micropolar lubricant. The theory of micropolar fluid gives the best descriptions of the non-Newtonian fluids containing additives substructures. There are many physical examples of micropolar fluids as ferrofluids, blood, bubbly liquids, and liquid crystals.19 The theory of micropolar fluids was formulated by Eringen.20 As per the definition, any fluid with suspended/dispersed particles altering its behavioral characteristics can be considered as micropolar fluids.20 Thus, all the present day lubricants utilizing the concepts of additive package can be considered as the micropolar fluids. This includes the lubricants belonging to the family of gear oil, turbine oil, bearing oil, hydraulic oil, engine oil, etc. Therefore, the problem addressed in this article has a wide scope of application as it involves all the present day lubricants. Theory of micropolar fluids describes that micropolar fluids exhibit special properties to support couple stress and body couple due to their microstructure and micro-rotational inertia at microscopic level.21 The first application of micropolar lubricant in fluid film bearings was carried out by Allen and Kline.22 Prakash and Sinha23 discussed the lubrication theory for micropolar fluid. They assumed a two-dimensional (2D) flow field and gave argument for order of magnitude analysis. Later on, Singh and Sinha24 derived 3D Reynolds equation for micropolar lubricated cylindrical journal bearing. Huang et al.25 and Khonsari and Brewe26 studied the performance of finite-width journal bearings with micropolar fluids. Huang and Weng27 presented the study of the dynamic characteristics of finite-width journal bearings with micropolar fluids. A study of micropolar lubricated hydrodynamic journal bearing with 3D irregularities has been carried out by Lin.28 A theoretical analysis of stability parameters of a micropolar lubricated bearing was performed by Das et al.29 Wang and Zhu30 studied the lubricating effectiveness of micropolar fluids in a dynamically loaded journal bearing. A numerical study to describe the non-Newtonian behavior of a micropolar lubricated finite journal bearing was carried out by Wang and Zhu.31 They studied the influence of material characteristic length and the coupling number on the thermohydrodynamic performance of a journal bearing. The studies by Rahmatabadi et al.32,33 addresses the influence of micropolar lubrication on the performance of circular and multilobe hydrodynamic journal bearings. The use of micropolar fluids results in an increase in load-carrying capacity and temperature, but the reduction in the value of coefficient of friction and side leakage flow as compared to Newtonian fluids.18,25–28,30–33

Naduvinamani and Santosh34 carried out a study dealing with micropolar fluid squeeze film lubrication of finite porous journal bearing. Wang et al.35 carried out a study of journal bearing system with combined influence of micropolar lubrication and cavitations effect. Lin et al.36 studied the effect of micropolar lubricant on the performance of parabolic-film slider bearings.

A thorough scan of the existing literature reveals that the available studies in the area of conical hydrostatic and hybrid journal bearing are mainly restricted to Newtonian lubricant. Further, no study has yet been reported in the literature that addresses the performance of a conical hydrostatic/hybrid journal bearing with membrane restrictor. Therefore, this study is aimed to bridge the gap in the literature and to analyze the performance of a membrane restricted conical hybrid journal bearing system operating with micropolar lubricant, as shown in Figure 1. The numerically simulated results in this study are expected to be beneficial to the bearing designers as well as to academic community. Figure 1.
Schematic of membrane restricted conical journal bearing system.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p:
The governing equations describing the behavior of micropolar fluids as derived by Eringen20 in vectorial form are expressed as (1)∂ρ∂t+∇ (ρ.V )=0
(2) (λ'+2μ )∇(∇.V)-12 (2μ+χ )∇×∇×V+χ∇×ϑ -∇p+ρB=ρdVdt
(3) (α1+β1+γ1 )∇ (∇.ϑ )-γ1∇×∇×ϑ+χ∇×V -2χϑ+ρL'=ρJdϑdt Since, the clearance between the journal and bearing is very small and the ratio, fluid film thickness to the mean radius of conical journal approaches to 10−3 to 10−4. Therefore, a conical journal bearing system can be modeled as flow of lubricant between two curvilinear plates, as shown in Figure 2. Thus, in cylindrical coordinate (θ,R,z ) system, the velocity, micro-rotation velocity, and pressure for a conical hybrid journal bearing system may be expressed as (4) V= (V1 (R,θ,z ),V2 (R,θ,z ),V3 (R,θ,z ) )ϑ= (ϑ1 (R,θ,z ),ϑ2 (R,θ,z ),ϑ3 (R,θ,z ) )p=p (R,θ,z ) } In cylindrical coordinate system, for an incompressible flow ( ∇ .V = 0), equations (1) to (3) can be written as follows.37 (5)1R∂ (ρRV1 )∂R+1R∂(ρV2)∂θ+∂(ρV3)∂z=0
(6)12 (2μ+χ ) [∂2∂R2+1R∂∂R+1R2∂2∂θ2+∂2∂z2 ]V1 +χ [1R∂ϑ3∂θ-∂ϑ2∂z ]-∂p∂R+ρBR =ρ [V1∂V1∂R+V2R∂V1∂θ+V3∂V1∂z-V1 2R ]
(7)12 (2μ+χ ) [∂2∂R2+1R∂∂R+1R2∂2∂θ2+∂2∂z2 ]V2 +χ [∂ϑ1∂z-∂ϑ3∂R ]-1R∂p∂θ+ρBθ =ρ [V1∂V2∂R+V2R∂V2∂θ+V3∂V2∂z+V1V2R ]
(8)12 (2μ+χ ) [∂2∂R2+1R∂∂R+1R2∂2∂θ2+∂2∂z2 ]V3 +χ [∂ϑ2∂R-1R∂ϑ1∂θ ]-∂p∂z+ρBZ =ρ [V1∂V3∂R+V2R∂V3∂θ+V3∂V3∂z ]
(9)γ1 [∂2∂R2+1R∂∂R+1R2∂2∂θ2+∂2∂z2 ]ϑ1 +χ [1R∂V3∂θ-∂V2∂z ]-2χϑ1+ρLR' =ρJ [ϑ1∂ϑ1∂R+ϑ2R∂ϑ1∂θ+ϑ3∂ϑ1∂z-ϑ1 2R ]
(10)γ1 [∂2∂R2+1R∂∂R+1R2∂2∂θ2+∂2∂z2 ]ϑ2 +χ [∂V1∂z-∂V3∂R ]-2χϑ2+ρLθ' =ρJ [ϑ1∂ϑ2∂R+ϑ2R∂ϑ2∂θ+ϑ3∂ϑ2∂z+ϑ1ϑ2R ]
(11)γ1 [∂2∂R2+1R∂∂R+1R2∂2∂θ2+∂2∂z2 ]ϑ3 +χ [∂V2∂R-1R∂V1∂θ ]-2χϑ3+ρLz' =ρJ [ϑ1∂ϑ3∂R+ϑ2R∂ϑ3∂θ+ϑ3∂ϑ3∂z ]
Figure 2.
Developed conical journal bearing system in cylindrical coordinate system.

In order to have a simplified analysis, the following assumptions are made in the analysis of a journal bearing system using micropolar theory.1,21,23,24,37–39
Body force and body couples are neglected. There is no internal force or internal couple in a bearing system. Hence, the terms pertaining to the body force and body couple from the basic equations of the micropolar theory (i.e. linear momentum and angular momentum equation) are neglected.
Flow of lubricant is laminar and incompressible. The flow of lubricant in the clearance space between journal and bearing is assumed to be incompressible and laminar.
The inertia forces and inertia couples are very small, therefore, neglected. In a lubrication problem, the viscous forces and couples are dominating, i.e. the values of inertia forces/inertia couples are very small as compared to viscous force/viscous couple, respectively. Therefore, the inertia forces and inertia couples are neglected. The inclusion of these terms results in a very slight change in the value of fluid film pressure which is insignificant.
Bearing system is isoviscous, isothermal, and rigid. The viscosity of the system is assumed to be constant during its operation. In this study, the effect of the bearing flexibility and thermal effect have not been considered.
All the characteristics coefficients are independent of Z. A lubrication problem concerning the journal bearing system takes into account the fact that, the clearance between a journal and bearing is very small (order of micron). Hence, the ratio of the fluid film thickness to the radius of journal approaches to 10−3 to 10−4. Therefore, a journal bearing system can be modeled as flow of lubricant between two rectangular plates. Similarly, flow of lubricant inside a conical journal bearing can be modeled as flow of lubricant between two curvilinear plates, as shown in Figure 2. Therefore, the changes in the values of the characteristics coefficients (α1, β1, γ1) are negligible across the fluid film thickness.
The pressure variation in Z-direction is negligible. As earlier discussed that the order of the fluid film thickness is very small, i.e. order of micron. Hence, the variation of the pressure across the fluid film thickness is very insignificant. Therefore, the pressure variation in Z-direction negligible.
Flow of lubricant in the clearance space between the journal and bearing is 2D. The flow of lubricant is only in R- and θ-directions, since the clearance space between journal and bearing is very small in Z-direction. Therefore, the flow of lubricant in the clearance space between the journal and bearing is 2D, i.e. (V3=ϑ3=0 ).
The velocity and micro-rotation velocity fields are independent of R-direction. The axial length of the bearing system is adequate that results, no change in the flow field with respect to axial dimension. In case of conical journal bearing, axial dimensional is proportional to R, as shown in Figure 2.

Equations (6) to (11) reduces to the following forms as (12)12 (2μ+χ )∂2V1∂z2-χ∂ϑ2∂z-∂p∂R=0
(13)12 (2μ+χ )∂2V2∂z2+χ∂ϑ1∂z-1R∂p∂θ=0
(14)γ1∂2ϑ1∂z2-2χϑ1-χ∂V2∂z=0
(15)γ1∂2ϑ2∂z2-2χϑ2+χ∂V1∂y=0 To determine the expressions of velocity field for micropolar lubricant, the following boundary conditions are incorporated in equations (12) to (15) (16) V1=0,V2=U,ϑ1=ϑ2=0atz=0V1=V2=0,ϑ1=ϑ2=0atz=h }

sec.title: The lubricant flow
sec.p: The local lubricant flow per unit width in R and θ directions can be obtained by integrating the respective velocity components across the local fluid film thickness is expressed as (17)qθ=∫0 hV2dzqθ=Uh2-Φ(N,l,h)12μ1R∂p∂θSimilarly,qR=∫0 hV1dz=-Φ(N,l,h)12μ∂p∂R where Φ(N,l,h)=h3+12l2h-6Nlh2coth (Nh2l ) is known as micropolar function N= (χ2μ+χ )1/2,l= (γ14μ )1/2 N and l are the characteristics parameter of micropolar lubricant. The dimensionless parameter N couples the linear and angular momentum equation, therefore named as coupling number. If the value of coupling number N becomes zero, then equation (2) turns to the basic Navier–Stokes equation of linear momentum. The parameter l has the dimension of length and plays a vital role in the modeling of the micropolar lubricant, hence called as characteristic length of the micropolar lubricant.

sec.title: Modified Reynolds equations
sec.p: The modified Reynolds equation applicable for a conical hybrid journal bearing system, as shown in Figure 1 is derived as follows.
The continuity equation in cylindrical coordinate system for 2D flow is given as37 follows (18)∂ρ∂t+1R∂(ρRV1)∂R+1R∂(ρV2)∂θ=0

Integration of equation (18) across the fluid film thickness, i.e. (0toh), and using equation (17), equation (18) yields (19)∂(ρh)∂t+1R∂(ρRqR)∂R+1R∂(ρqθ)∂θ=0For incompressible fluid,∂h∂t+1R∂(RqR)∂R+1R∂qθ∂θ=0

Substituting the value of qR and qθ in equation (19) 1R∂∂R [RΦ(N,l,h)12μ∂p∂R ]+1R2∂∂θ [Φ(N,l,h)12μ∂p∂θ ] =121R∂(Uh)∂θ+∂h∂t Substituting the values of the parameters as U=rω, θ=αsinγ, and R=rsinγ (20)1R∂∂R [RΦ(N,l,h)12μ∂p∂R ]+1(Rsinγ)2∂∂α [Φ(N,l,h)12μ∂p∂α ] =12ω∂h∂α+∂h∂t Using following non-dimensionalization parameters, equation (20) is reduced as40 (21)β=Rsinγrj;p¯=pps;l¯=cl;h¯=hc;t¯=t / [μrj 2c2ps ];Ω=ωj [c2psμrj 2 ];Φ¯ (N,l¯,h¯ )=Φ (N,l,h )c3sin2γβ∂∂β [βΦ¯ (N,l¯,h¯ )12∂p¯∂β ] +1β2∂∂α [Φ¯ (N,l¯,h¯ )12∂p¯∂α ]=12Ω∂h¯∂α+∂h¯∂t¯

Equation (21) is the modified Reynolds equation for a conical journal bearing system operating with micropolar lubricant. For the values of micropolar parameters, l¯=∞,N=o, equation (21) changes into the form applicable for Newtonian lubricant, as given in Sharma et al.12,13 For values l¯=∞ and N = 0, any micropolar lubricant behaves like a Newtonian lubricant.

sec.title: Restrictor flow equation
sec.p: For a membrane compensated multirecess journal bearing system as shown in Figure 1, the lubricant flow rate through various pockets: j = 1, 2, 3, … np may be expressed in its non-dimensional form as14–18 (22) Q¯R1=C¯s2[1+C¯m(P¯c1-P¯c3)]3(1-P¯c1)Q¯R2=C¯s2[1+C¯m(P¯c2-P¯c4)]3(1-P¯c2)Q¯R3=C¯s2[1+C¯m(P¯c1-P¯c3)]3(1-P¯c3)Q¯R4=C¯s2[1+C¯m(P¯c2-P¯c4)]3(1-P¯c4) } where the terms P¯c1, P¯c2, P¯c3, and P¯c4 indicate the values of fluid film pressure in respective recesses/pockets C¯=psAmKmhmo=membrane compliance
The non-dimensional flow rate equations for a membrane restrictor becomes similar to a capillary restrictor when C¯=0.
The stiffness of the membrane Km is given as (23)Km=4πEtm 3(ξ2-1)3(1-υ2)r2 2[(ξ2-1)2-4ξ2(lnξ)2] where ξ = r3/r2.

sec.title: Finite element formulation
sec.p:
Applying the finite element method using the orthogonality condition of Galerkin’s technique in equation (21), the following elemental equation (24) in matrix form is obtained (24) [F¯ij ]e {p¯ }e= {Q¯ }e+Ω {R¯H }e+X·¯j {R¯Xj }e+Z·¯j {R¯Zj }e where F¯ij e=∫∫Ωe' [Φ¯(N,l¯,h¯)12 (1sinγ∂Ni∂α∂Nj∂α+β2sinγ∂Ni∂β∂Nj∂β ) ] ×dαdβ
Q¯i e=∮ΓeΦ¯(N,l¯,h¯)12 [1sinγ∂p¯∂αnα+β2sinγ∂p¯∂βnβ ]Nip¯jdΓ -Ω2 ∮ΓeNiβ2sinγh¯nαdΓR¯Hi e=12∫∫Ωe'h¯∂Ni∂αβ2sinγdαdβR¯Xji e=∫∫Ωe'cosαcosγβ2sinγNidαdβR¯Zji e=∫∫Ωe'sinαcosγβ2sinγNidαdβ where nα and nβ are the direction cosines and i, j = 1, 2, 3, 4 (number of nodes per element). Ωe represents the area domain and Γe the boundary domain of the eth element. The lubricant film has been discretized using the four noded quadrilateral isoparametric elements.

sec.title: Boundary conditions
sec.p:
The boundary conditions used for the analysis of lubricant flow field are described as:
The nodes lying on external boundary of bearing have zero relative pressure with respect to ambient pressure, i.e. p¯ |β=∓1.0=0.0.
Nodes lying on a recess have equal pressure.
Flow of lubricant through the restrictor is equal to the bearing input flow.
At the trailing edge of positive region, the Reynolds boundary condition is applied; i.e. p¯=∂p¯∂α=0.0.

sec.title: Fluid film stiffness and damping coefficients
sec.p: The fluid film stiffness coefficients are defined as the negative derivative of the load capacity with respect to the journal center displacement. Mathematically, fluid film stiffness coefficient are defined as (25)S¯ij=-∂F¯i∂q¯j;(i=x,z) where i is the direction of force and q¯j the components of the journal center displacement (q¯j=X¯j,Z¯j).
The fluid film damping coefficients are defined as (26)c¯ij=-∂F¯i∂q·¯j;(i=x,z)
Here, q·¯j represents the velocity component of journal center q·¯j=X·¯j,Z·¯j.

sec.title: Stability parameters
sec.p: Using the Routh’s stability criteria, the stability parameters are defined as follows.

The non-dimensional critical mass (M¯c) for the journal bearing system for lateral motion is expressed as (27)M¯c=G¯1G¯2-G¯3 where G¯1= [C¯11C¯22-C¯21C¯12 ];G¯2= [S¯11S¯22-S¯12S¯21 ] [C¯11+C¯22 ] [S¯11C¯22+S¯22C¯11-S¯12C¯21-S¯21C¯12 ];G¯3= [S¯11C¯11+S¯12C¯12+S¯21C¯21+S¯22C¯22 ] [C¯11+C¯12 ]; Threshold speed, i.e. the speed of journal at the threshold of instability, can be obtained using the relation as follows: (28)ω¯th= [M¯C /M¯CF¯0 F¯0 ]1 /1 2 2 where F¯0 is resultant fluid film force or reaction at ∂h¯∂t¯=0

sec.title: Solution procedure
sec.p:
The solution of the fluid flow field of four-pockets conical hybrid journal bearing system operating with both Newtonian and micropolar fluid is obtained using a suitable iterative scheme to solve the flow field equation (24) and restrictor flow equation (22) simultaneously with appropriate boundary conditions. A block diagram to describe the overall solution scheme has been shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
A block diagram to describe the overall solution scheme.

For a membrane compensated journal bearing system, in order to maintain continuity of flow between bearing and restrictor, the modified Reynolds equation (24) becomes non-linear in nature. Therefore, Newton–Raphson iterative technique is used to solve the non-linear modified Reynolds equation (24). The detailed description of this iterative technique has been presented in Sharma et al.18 The unit INDAT reads the input data and the 2D mesh of the bearing system. Then, unit FTHIK calculates the fluid film thickness at nodal points for the tentative values of the journal center position. In unit FEQ, the fluidity matrix is generated and globalized as per the connectivity of the elements. In block NWRAP, the restrictor flow field equation is solved using Newton–Raphson Method. The unit BCNS applies all the boundary conditions described in ‘Boundary conditions.’ In unit SLEQ, the modified Reynolds equation is solved for the fluid film nodal pressure using Gaussian elimination technique. The load-carrying capacities are calculated in Block LODM. Utilizing the value of F¯x and F¯z as result of the unit LODM, the journal center equilibrium position is obtained in unit PREQ. This iterative process is continued until the convergence criterion describes in equation (29) is satisfied. The other performance characteristics parameters are calculated in unit POPRO (29)PERR= [ { (ΔX¯j i )2+ (ΔZ¯j i )2 }1/2 { (X¯j i )2+ (Z¯j i )2 }1/2 ] ×100≤TOLIM<0.001

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
In this section, the performance characteristics of a four-pocket hybrid journal bearing system having different semi-cone angles for the typical values of micropolar parameters (coupling number and characteristics length) have been presented. A source program was developed in FORTRAN 77 using the analysis, as described in earlier sections. In order to validate the methodology adopted in this study, the results of capillary compensated conical hydrostatic journal bearing have been compared with the results of Stout and Rowe.3 Figure 4(a) shows a favorable agreement of the results of this study with the already published results3 with an error of 1–4%. As there are no results available for micropolar lubricated conical hydrostatic/hybrid journal bearing system, thus for the validation of the micropolar analysis, the results of micropolar effect for the case of a circular hydrodynamic journal bearing have been compared with the already published results of Khonsari and Brewe26 and Wang and Zhu.31 It may be noticed from Figure 4(b), the present results validate well with already published result26 with an error of 1–3%. Figure 4(c) also shows a favorable match between present results and the already published results31 with an error of 1–4%. Further, the present results for membrane restricted hydrostatic journal bearing have been also compared with the already publish results of Cusano,15 as shown in Figure 4(d). Figure 4.
(a) Radial load capacity (W¯r) vs eccentricity ratio (ɛr); (b) load-carrying capacity (F¯o) vs eccentricity ratio (ɛ); (c) load-carrying capacity (Fo) vs eccentricity ratio (ɛ); and (d) load-carrying capacity (Fo) vs pressure ratio (β*).

The behavioral aspect of micropolar lubricants is defined in terms of coupling number (N) and the characteristics length (l). The coupling number (N) is a function of dynamic viscosity (μ) and the spin viscosity (χ). These parameters for a real micropolar lubricant can be determined using rheological experiments on capillary and rotational viscometers. The characteristics length (l) is a function of dynamic viscosity (μ) and material coefficient (γ1). The values of ‘l’ can be determined by conducting rheological and material characteristic experiments. Thus, in order to specify the values for ‘l’ and ‘N’ rigorous experimentation needs to be undertaken which stands beyond the scope of this article. However, for an experimental determination of micropolar fluid constants, a study by Kolpashchikov et al.41 is only available in the literature. This study deals with the experimental evaluation of micropolar constants for water. This article deals with the study of performance behavior of membrane compensated four-pocket hybrid conical journal bearing operating with the micropolar lubricants. The micropolar lubricant parameters used in this study represents lubricants that are generally used for continuous operation of machinery and have been quite widely used. These parameters have been chosen from the available literature,23,25–36 indicated in Table 1 Table 1.
Micropolar parameters in different lubrication problems.
S. no. Relevant studies Values of micropolar parameters
N2 l¯
1 Prakash and Sinha23 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 0.9, 1.0 3, 5, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12, 15, 18
2 Huang et al.25 0.33 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30
3 Khonsari et al.26 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9 1, 10, 20, 30, 40
4 Huang and Weng27 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30
5 Lin28 0.1, 0.5, 0.8 2, 10
6 Wang and Zhu30 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9 1, 9, 10, 20, 30

8 Rahmatabadi et al.32 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.9 9, 10, 20, 30, 40
9 Rahmatabadi et al.33 0.1, 0.3, 0.5, 0.9 1, 2, 3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, 40
10 Naduvinamani and Santosh34 0.2, 0.4, 0.6 5, 10
11 Wang et al.35 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 10, 20, 30
12 Lin et al.36 0.3, 0.5 2, 3.33, 10

Table 2 indicates the judiciously selected typical values of the geometric and operating parameters of the journal bearing system. The selection of the bearing geometric and operating parameters is based on the available literature. The selection of a four-pocket bearing has been preferred over higher number of pocket from the viewpoint of h¯min, Q¯, and S¯zz.42 The performance characteristics parameters of bearing system have been plotted with respect to external radial load (W¯r) and with respect to characteristic length (l¯) for different values of semi-cone angles and for both Newtonian and micropolar lubricant, as per Figures 5 to 11. The performance characteristics parameters have also been tabulated in Table 3 for different values of semi-cone angles at the constant value of radial load (W¯r=0.5). The influences of the bearing operating parameters on bearing performance characteristics have been presented in the following section. Figure 5.
(a) Variation of maximum pressure (p¯max) vs radial load (W¯r) and (b) variation of maximum pressure (p¯max) vs characteristic length (l¯).
Table 2.
Geometric and operating parameters for conical journal bearing system.
Bearing aspect ratio, λ 1.0
Number of pockets 4
Restrictor design (C¯s2) parameter 0.50
Type of compensating element Membrane
Compliance of the membrane, (C¯m) 0.25, 0.15
Non-dimensional external radial load, (W¯r) 0.1–0.9
Semi-cone angle, γ 10°, 20°, 30°, 40°
Total pocket area to total bearing area, Ap/Ab 0.333
Speed parameter, Ω 1.0
Land width ratio, (a¯b) 0.25
Characteristic length, (l¯) 15, 20, 30, 40, 50
Coupling number parameter, N2 0.4, 0.5
Table 3.
Bearing performance characteristics of four-pocket conical hybrid journal bearing system operating with Newtonian and micropolar lubricant with different semi-cone angles.

sec.title: Influence on the maximum fluid film pressure (p¯max)
sec.p: For a conical hybrid journal bearing system, the value of maximum fluid film pressure (p¯max) increases with an increase in the value of external radial load (W¯r) for both Newtonian and micropolar lubricant for different semi-cone angles, as shown in Figure 5(a). It may be observed that for a constant value of external load, the effect of the micropolar lubricant is to raise the value of maximum fluid film pressure. Further, the micropolar lubrication effect increases with an increase in the value of coupling number. For the value of micropolar parameter N2=0.5,l¯=20, the value of maximum fluid film pressure increases by a factor of 8.39%, 8.47%, 8.33%, and 10.89% vis-à-vis Newtonian lubricant for semi-cone angles 10∘, 20∘, 30∘, and 40∘, respectively. Figure 5(b) shows the variation of maximum fluid film pressure with respect to characteristic length (l¯) at the constant radial load (W¯r=0.5) for values of membrane compliance (C¯m=0.15,0.25) and for the values of semi-cone angles 10∘, 20∘, and 30∘. For same values of membrane compliance, the values of maximum fluid film pressure have been also obtained for semi-cone angle γ=40∘ but for the brevity have not been plotted in Figure 5(b). As the value of characteristic length increases, the micropolar effect of the lubricant tends to decrease which results in a decrease in the value of p¯max. The value of p¯max decreases more rapidly with the value of (l¯) up to (l¯=30). Another notable observation from Figure 5(b) is that for a constant value of external load, the value of p¯max increases with an increase in the value of membrane compliance. Further, it may be observed from Figure 5(a) and (b) that an increase in the value of semi-cone angle results in an increase in the value of p¯max for a constant value of external load for either Newtonian or micropolar lubricant.

sec.title: Influence on the minimum fluid film thickness (h¯min)
sec.p:
The influence on the minimum fluid film thickness (h¯min) of the bearing system has been shown in Figure 6(a) and (b). Figure 6(a) shows that the value of h¯min decreases with an increase in the value of radial load since the fluid film pressure increases. For the constant value of W¯r, the use of micropolar lubricant results in a marginal increase in the value of h¯min for different values of semi-cone angle. Moreover, for a specific value of W¯r, the bearing configuration, having semi-cone angle γ=10∘ provides the maximum value of h¯min. This may be attributed to the fact that the for a conical journal bearing fluid film thickness is a function of the cosine of semi-cone angle γ. Therefore, the values of fluid film thickness get reduced with an increase in semi-cone angle. Hence, the value of minimum fluid film thickness decreases with an increase in semi-cone angle. Figure 6(b) shows the variation in the value of h¯min with respect to characteristic length (l¯) for the specific value of radial load W¯r=0.5. It may also be obtained from Figure 6(b) that as the value of membrane compliance increases, the value of h¯min increases. Another notable observation from Figure 6(b) is that for micropolar lubricant, the value of h¯min decreases up to l¯=30, beyond that the value of h¯min becomes almost constant for different values of semi-cone angle. Figure 6.
(a) Variation of minimum fluid film thickness (h¯min) vs radial load (W¯r) and (b) variation of minimum fluid film thickness (h¯min) vs characteristic length (l¯).

sec.title: Influence on the bearing flow (Q¯)
sec.p:
It may also be shown from Figure 7(a) that as the value of external radial load W¯r increases, the value of bearing flow (Q¯). decreases. It is due to the fact that the value of minimum fluid film thickness decreases with an increase in the value of W¯r. An increase in the micropolar lubrication effect results in a decrease in the value of bearing flow. For the value of micropolar parameter N2=0.5,l¯=20, the value of Q¯ reduces by a factor of 10.68%, 11.78%, 13.90%, and 20.89% vis-à-vis Newtonian lubricant for semi-cone angles 10∘, 20∘, 30∘, and 40∘, respectively. Figure 7(b) indicates that for a micropolar lubricated bearing system, an increase in the value of l¯ results in an increase in value of bearing flow. Further, it may also be noticed that as the value of bearing compliance increases, the value of bearing flow decreases. The value of bearing flow decreases with an increase in the value of semi-cone angle, as shown in Figure 7(a) and (b). Figure 7.
(a) Variation of flow (Q¯) vs radial load (W¯r) and (b) variation of flow (Q¯) vs characteristic length (l¯).

sec.title: Influence on the fluid film stiffness coefficients (S¯xx,S¯zz)
sec.p:
The variation of direct fluid film stiffness coefficients (S¯xx,S¯zz) have been shown in Figure 8(a) to (d) for both Newtonian and micropolar lubricant for different values of semi-cone angles. The values of cross coupled fluid film stiffness coefficient (S¯xz,S¯zx) also have been computed in the study bur these characteristics have not been presented for the sake of brevity. Figure 8(a) and (c) shows the variation in the value of S¯xx,S¯zz with respect to W¯r sequentially. It may be observed from Figure 8(a) that for a constant value of radial load, the value of S¯xx increases with an increase in micropolar effect for the values of semi-cone angles 10∘, 20∘, and 30∘ but for semi-cone angle γ=40∘, the value of S¯xx decreases with a rise in micropolar effect. Whereas, the value of S¯zz always increases with micropolar effect, as shown in Figure 8(c). However, for micropolar lubricant, the percentage increase in the values of (S¯xx,S¯zz) decreases with an increase in the value of semi-cone angle. Another notable observation from Figure 8(c) is that the value of S¯zz decreases with radial load for the values of semi-cone angle 10∘, 20∘, and 30∘ while for the case of semi-cone angle γ=40∘, the value of S¯zz increases. Figure 8(b) and (d) shows the variation of (S¯xx,S¯zz) with respect to characteristic length of the micropolar lubricant for a constant value of W¯r=0.5. As the value of l¯ increases, the values of (S¯xx,S¯zz) decrease for different values of semi-cone angle. It may also be observed from Figure 8(b) and (d) that as the value of membrane compliance increases, the value of (S¯xx,S¯zz) increases for either Newtonian or micropolar lubricant. Figure 8.
(a) Variation of direct stiffness coefficient (S¯xx) vs radial load (W¯r); (b) variation of direct stiffness coefficient (S¯xx) vs characteristic length (l¯); (c) variation of direct stiffness coefficient (S¯zz) vs radial load (W¯r); and (d) variation of direct stiffness coefficient (S¯zz) vs characteristic length (l¯).

sec.title: Influence on the fluid film damping coefficients (C¯xx,C¯zz)
sec.p:
Figure 9(a) to (d) shows the variation of direct fluid film damping coefficients (C¯xx,C¯zz). The cross coupled fluid film damping coefficients (C¯xz,C¯zx) have been also computed but due to brevity, these have not been plotted. The influence of external radial load on the values of (C¯xx,C¯zz) has been shown in Figure 9(a) and (c), respectively. With an increase in the value of W¯r, the value of C¯xx increases while the value of C¯zz decreases. It may also be seen that for a constant value of radial load, the use of micropolar lubricant increases the values of (C¯xx,C¯zz) vis-à-vis Newtonian lubricant. It may also be observed from Figure 9(a) that for the value of micropolar parameter N2=0.5,l¯=20, the value of C¯xx increases by a factor of 13.54%, 13.0%, 11.82%, and 9.41% vis-à-vis Newtonian lubricant for semi-cone angles 10∘, 20∘, 30∘, and 40∘, respectively. Figure 9(b) and (d) shows that as the value of characteristic length of the micropolar lubricant increases, the values of (C¯xx,C¯zz) decrease. Further, higher value of membrane compliance results in higher values of damping coefficients (C¯xx,C¯zz). Moreover, the value of fluid film damping coefficients increases with an increase in the value of semi-cone angle. Figure 9.
(a) Variation of direct damping coefficient (C¯xx) vs radial load (W¯r); (b) variation of direct damping coefficient (C¯xx) vs characteristic length (l¯); (c) variation of direct damping coefficient (C¯zz) vs radial load (W¯r); and (d) variation of direct damping coefficient (C¯zz) vs characteristic length (l¯).

sec.title: Influence on the stability parameters (M¯c,ω¯th)
sec.p:
Stability is the highly desirable performance parameter of a hybrid bearing system. In this study, both the stability parameters critical mass and threshold speed margin (M¯c,ω¯th) have been plotted with respect to external radial load in Figure 10(a) to (c) and with respect to characteristic length in Figure 10(b) to (d). The values of stability parameters (M¯c,ω¯th) increase with the use of micropolar lubricant vis-à-vis Newtonian lubricant for the values of semi-cone angle 10∘, 20∘, and 30∘, where as for the case of semi-cone angle γ=40∘, the values of stability parameters (M¯c,ω¯th) decrease with micropolar lubricant vis-à-vis Newtonian lubricant. This fact can be explained that the stability parameters are the functions of fluid film stiffness coefficients. It may also be observed from Figure 10(c) there is a rapid decrease in the value of threshold speed margin with respect to radial load for either Newtonian and micropolar lubricant. Another notable observation from Figure 10(b) and (d) is that for a constant value of external load, the values of stability parameters (M¯c,ω¯th) increases with an increase in the value membrane compliance for both Newtonian and micropolar lubricant. The bearing configuration with semi-cone angle 40∘ provides the larger values of stability margin than the other bearing configuration operating with both Newtonian and micropolar lubricant. This may be attributed to the fact that the stability margin is a function of bearing rotor dynamic coefficients. The conical journal bearing system having semi-cone angle of 40∘ provides the larger values of fluid film pressures than that of the other semi-cone angles. This results in higher values of rotor dynamic coefficients vis-à-vis other semi-cone angle studied. Figure 10.
(a) Variation of critical mass (M¯c) vs radial load (W¯r); (b) variation of critical mass (M¯c) vs characteristic length (l¯); (c) variation of threshold speed margin (ω¯th) vs radial load (W¯r); and (d) variation of threshold speed margin (ω¯th) vs characteristic length (l¯).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
An analytical study of membrane compensated four-pocket hybrid conical journal bearing system operating with micropolar lubricant has been carried out. On the basis of the numerically simulated results presented, the following conclusions have been drawn.
With an increase in micropolar effect of the lubricant, the value of minimum fluid film thickness h¯min increases. An increase in the value of semi-cone angle results in a reduction in the value of h¯min. The value of h¯min increases with an increase in the value of membrane compliance for both Newtonian and micropolar lubricant.
The value of bearing flow Q¯ reduces by order of 10–20% using the micropolar lubricant vis-à-vis Newtonian lubricant for different semi-cone angles. For same operating parameters, the requirement of flow gets reduced with an increase in semi-cone angle. As the compliance of the membrane increases, the value of the bearing flow reduces.
The use of micropolar lubricant results in an increase in the value of fluid film stiffness and damping coefficients for the values of semi-cone angle 10∘, 20∘, and 30∘. The values of fluid film stiffness and damping coefficients increases with an increase in bearing compliance. As the value of semi-cone angle increases, the value of (S¯xx,S¯zz) increases for either Newtonian and micropolar lubricant.
The stability margin in terms of critical journal mass and stability threshold speed increases for a micropolar lubricated bearing, for the values of semi-cone angle 10∘, 20∘, and 30∘. The bearing configuration with semi-cone angle 40∘ provides the larger values of stability margin than the other bearing configuration operating with both Newtonian and micropolar lubricant. The following pattern for the stability threshold speed margin has been observed from this study
ω¯th|γ=40deg>ω¯th|γ=30deg>ω¯th|γ=20deg>ω¯th|γ=10deg

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
